case_vignette: An 18-year-old man presents to the student health department at his university for recurrent palpitations. The patient had previously presented to the emergency department (ED) for sudden onset palpitations five months ago when he first started college. He had a negative cardiac workup in the ED and he was discharged with a 24-hour Holter monitor which was also negative. He has no history of any medical or psychiatric illnesses. The patient reports that since his initial ED visit, he has had several episodes of unprovoked palpitations associated with feelings of dread and lightheadedness though he cannot identify a particular trigger. Recently, he has begun sitting towards the back of the lecture halls so that he can “quickly escape and not make a scene” in case he gets an episode in class.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having these episodes where my heart suddenly starts racing for no reason, and I feel really scared and kind of dizzy.
Great, thank you for sharing that information. Can you tell me more about the duration of these episodes? How long do they last?
They don't last very long, but I haven't timed them exactly.

Okay, no problem. And have you noticed any other symptoms along with the racing heart and dizziness? For example, do you feel short of breath, have chest pain, or experience any numbness or weakness in your face or limbs?
No, I haven't noticed any other symptoms like that.

Alright, thank you for letting me know. Have you noticed any triggers that make these episodes worse or more likely to occur? For example, do you experience them more frequently after exercise, stress, or certain activities?
I can't really pinpoint any specific triggers for these episodes; they seem to happen out of the blue.

Okay, that's not uncommon. Have you had any recent changes in your life, such as a new job, move, or relationship, that could be contributing to these episodes? Sometimes, significant life changes can affect your mental health and lead to symptoms like this.
Well, the first time it happened was when I first started college about five months ago.

I see. It's possible that the stress of starting college and adjusting to a new environment could be contributing to these episodes. Many students experience anxiety and stress during this time, and it can manifest in physical symptoms like a racing heart and dizziness. Have you talked to anyone about how you're feeling? It might be helpful to speak with a counselor or therapist about your symptoms and how they're affecting your daily life.
I haven't talked to anyone professional about it yet, but I suppose it might be a good idea.

Absolutely! It can be helpful to talk to a mental health professional about your symptoms and how they're affecting you. They can help you identify the underlying causes of your symptoms and develop strategies to manage them. It's important to remember that you don't have to go through this alone, and seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness.

In the meantime, there are some things you can try to help manage your symptoms. Have you tried any relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation? These can help calm your mind and body.

Also, have you considered keeping a journal to track when your symptoms occur and what might be triggering them? This can help you identify patterns and triggers, which can be helpful in managing your symptoms.

Remember, it's okay to take things one step at a time. You don't have to have all the answers right away. Just taking small steps towards seeking help and managing your symptoms can make a big difference.
Yeah, I've started sitting in the back of the lecture halls so if I need to, I can leave quickly without causing a scene.

Ah, I see. It sounds like you're taking some proactive steps to manage your anxiety in the lecture halls. Sitting in the back of the room can be a good way to feel more comfortable and in control of your environment, while still being close enough to hear the lecture and participate if you need to.

It's also important to remember that it's okay to take breaks and step outside for some fresh air or to grab a snack if you're feeling overwhelmed. Many universities have designated break areas or outdoor spaces where you can take a break without feeling like you're missing out on important information.

In addition to these strategies, have you considered talking to your professors or a counselor about your anxiety? They may be able to offer additional support or accommodations to help you manage your anxiety in the lecture halls.

Remember, you don't have to go through this alone. There are many resources available to help you manage your anxiety and succeed in your studies.
I'll think about talking to someone at the university for help. Thanks for the suggestion.

You're welcome! It's great that you're considering seeking help from the university. They may have resources such as counseling services or academic support that can help you manage your anxiety and succeed in your studies.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. It's a sign of strength, not weakness. And don't hesitate to reach out to me or other friends and family members for support. We're here to help you through this challenging time.

Take care of yourself and stay positive. You got this!
